Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: The shrill ring of my phone jolted me from my focus, eyes glued to the radar screen. It was 2:13 a.m., and the airspace was a tangled mess—dozens of flights circling, pilots anxious, my headset crackling with urgent requests. I couldn’t afford a single mistake. But when I saw my friend’s name flash on my phone, I knew something was wrong. I answered, and her voice was raw, trembling—she could barely get the words out. Her father had just passed away. She needed me, needed someone to listen, to anchor her in the storm. My heart twisted. I wanted to be there for her, to offer comfort, to let her know she wasn’t alone. But in front of me, the radar pulsed with responsibility—hundreds of lives depended on my focus, my decisions. My friend’s sobs filled my ear, while pilots’ voices filled my headset. I felt split in two, torn between the person who needed me most and the job that demanded my undivided attention. My hands hovered, uncertain, as I wrestled with the impossible choice.
